newsitem.title: USA: US House passes FY98 ag fund bill with EEP cap.
newsitem.headline: US House passes FY98 ag fund bill with EEP cap.

text.p: The U.S. House, after rejecting attempts to trim sugar and peanut supports, passed a $49.5 billion agriculture appropriations bill for fisal 1998 that included a $205 million cap on the major ag export subsidy program.

The administration requested $500 million for the Export Enhancement Program. The House settled on $205 million, partly to cover the cost of crop insurance sales commissions. The Senate passed its version of the FY98 funding bill earlier in the day with a $150 million limit on EEP.

Representatives passed the bill, 392-32. The Senate passed its version of the bill earlier today. The next step would be a "conference" by House and Senate negotiators to resolve differences over crop insurance sales commissions, $91 million in drug user fees for the Food and Drug Administration, EEP funding levels, and other points of disagreement.
The House bill included $5.7 billion for ag export credit guarantees, $90 million for the Market Access Program and $879 million for the PL-480 Food for Peace sales and humanitarian donation program.

During the final day of work, representatives rejected 216-209 a proposal to ban federally subsidized crop insurance for tobacco; defeated 253-175 a change in the sugar program intended to lower prices, turned down 222-185 a proposal to reduce the peanut support price by $60 per ton, and refused 277-150 to eliminate funding for the $90 million a year Market Access Program.

Lawmakers also refused to transfer $14 million in crop insurance funding to antismoking programs or to move $23.7 million from crop insurance to boost funding for the Women, Infants and Children feeding program.
